Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Next Generation Solvers for Mixed Integer Nonlinear Programs: Structure, Search, and Implementation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Collaborative Research: Next-Generation Solvers for Mixed-Integer<br/> Nonlinear Programs: Structure, Search, and Implementation<br/><br/>Many scientific, engineering, and public sector applications involve<br/>both discrete decisions and nonlinear system dynamics that affect the<br/>optimality of the final design. Mixed-integer nonlinear programming<br/>(MINLP) optimization problems combine the difficulty of optimizing over<br/>discrete variable sets with the challenges of handling nonlinear<br/>functions. MINLP is one of the most flexible modeling paradigms<br/>available, and an expanding body of researchers and practitioners,<br/>including computer scientists, engineers, economists, statisticians, and<br/>operations managers, are interested in solving large-scale MINLPs.<br/>Unfortunately, the wealth of applications that can be accurately modeled<br/>by using MINLP is not yet matched by the capability of available<br/>algorithms and software. This research will address the mismatch<br/>between natural optimization models and available robust optimization<br/>solvers, developing and delivering powerful new solvers for<br/>mixed-integer nonlinear programs. <br/><br/>The research thrusts are in three main categories. In the first thrust,<br/>the investigators study the structure of fundamental MINLP models,<br/>developing preprocessing techniques and strong valid inequalities. The<br/>second thrust, search, leverages the results of the structural analyses<br/>to design search and partitioning strategies for algorithms. The third<br/>thrust, implementation, focuses on implementing the resulting<br/>algorithmic frameworks efficiently on modern computational resources.<br/>The project has the transformative goal of making MINLP into an area in<br/>which researchers and practitioners can access robust tools and methods<br/>capable of solving a wide range of important, commonly occurring<br/>decision support problems.<br/><br/>
